page.title: 10Nash Lighthouse
page.content: Nash Lighthouse was established in 1832 to mark the sandbanks off the point at the entrance to the Bristol Channel. The decision to build it followed a public outcry after the passenger steamer FROLIC was wrecked with heavy loss of life in 1830. Two circular towers were built each with massive walls and a stone gallery.Placed 330 yards apart,the eastern illuminant is 125ft.high and the western one 73ft.high.They provided leading lights to indicate safe passage past the sandbanks.In those days each had either a fixed red or white light visible to approaching shipping depending upon their course.The low light was abandoned early this century and the high light was eventually electrified in 1971.
